channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Hundreds of Companies and CEOs Sign Pro-Voting Access Letter
item.description: Former American Express CEO Kenneth Chenault and Merck CEO Kenneth Frazier, two high-profile Black corporate leaders, led the effort. They did, however, all put out their own statements on the issue preceding the passage of Georgia’s controversial law.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Bernard L. Madoff Dies at 82 in Prison After Largest Ponzi Scheme in History
item.description: Madoff orchestrated the biggest investment fraud in US history, costing his investors a total of $64.8 billion and earning him a 150-year prison sentence. Zoom out: While Madoff claimed he was the sole organizer, more than a dozen people, including his brother Peter Madoff, were convicted of federal crimes.  At 22, Madoff started his investment company in 1960.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: How Forbes 30 Under 30’s Phillip Aubrey Does His Taxes
item.description: MB: Can you tell us one do or don’t?  PA: A lot of people, especially on the startup side, tend to think whatever money they raise they can use all willy nilly.  MB: Before we bring it back to taxes, what’s one thing you learned while working with Alexis? Then we swapped cards so no one had their own, and anyone who wanted to take money out of their account had to go back to the group and ask the group to release their funds.    PA: QuickBooks makes it very easy for us to categorize expenses, so when we hand things over to our accountant, it’s not difficult to understand where money went and is going.  MB: What’s tough about it?  MB: I know this is supposed to be a tax interview but I have to ask, you were working for Alexis Ohanian’s Initialized Capital before you left to run Yunit full-time.  PA: Even being able to answer some of the questions that our tax professional is asking to make sure they’re doing the paperwork correctly. Over a two-year period, not one person took money out of their account. The biggest benefit is we can very easily share ownership or sell shares of the company, whereas most other incorporation types don’t make that easy. The next stage is to make the app publicly available and allow people to start their own savings groups. He discussed the importance of keeping personal and business money separate, the power of using community to reach your financial goals, and the ups and downs of creating the world he wants to see.  PA: Alexis is a dreamer, and I love it. For example, keeping personal money separate from business money.  PA: My goal was to go out and raise venture money because I knew that I wanted to scale the business, and 99% of venture-backed businesses are a Delaware C-corp, which we are as well.  PA: It came a few years ago, when a partner was fired at a company where I worked.  PA: We are doing our private beta now, which is very exciting because I’m getting some great feedback. It shocked me because I didn’t know at the time that partners could be fired. And yet, no one was managing their money well.  MB: So how is Yunit structured as a business, and why did you decide to incorporate that way? So I reached out to that same person and asked him to help us out with our taxes.  Phillip Aubrey: Yunit is a mobile app that makes it easy for friends and family to save money together. You learn quickly what you can and cannot do.
item.author: Devin Tomb

item.title: Q&A: What Are Company Earnings, Why do They Affect Stocks?
item.description: Question from Reha in Boston: How does a company's quarterly earnings report affect its stock price? But an earnings report can also show metrics like revenue, subscriber counts (in the case of companies like Netflix), and predictions for future performance, aka "guidance." Then, execs usually host a conference call to parse the data in front of analysts and whichever media interns drew the short stick."
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: The Boba Supply Chain Is Drying Up
item.description: It's a lot to chew on: Big-time boba shop Boba Guys posted an Instagram video explaining that 99% of US boba is imported from overseas. The slurpable little tapioca balls are the latest victim of a pandemic-strapped supply chain, reports the SF Chronicle.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 14
item.description: (Emerging Tech Brew) Read: Your definitive guide to autonomous vehicles. The main culprits: wealthy Americans and large corporations.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Consumer Prices Rise More Than Expected in March
item.description: US consumer prices increased the most in nearly nine years in March: 0.6% over the prior month and 2.6% over last year. Some economists are concerned that too much stimulus will cause an overheated economy.   Looking ahead…the Fed expects a temporary bump in prices that will smooth out once supply chains figure their Suez out.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Grab Set To Become The Biggest SPAC Merger to Date
item.description: Through the deal, Grab will raise $4 billion to tap the pandemic-driven influx of ~40 million Southeast Asians estimated to have gotten online for the first time in 2020.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: US Regulators Recommend Pause for Johnson & Johnson Vaccine
item.description: Yesterday, Johnson & Johnson joined millions of disappointed students on dreaded waitlists after the CDC and FDA recommended pausing its single-dose Covid vaccine while they investigate reports of rare blood clots. the CDC committee that makes recommendations on immunization practices meets today to discuss when J&J's one shot gets a second shot.  The agencies say this is out of an "abundance of caution" while they determine if the vaccine caused rare blood clots and low platelet counts in six women shortly after their vaccinations.  To-date, J&J has accounted for <5% of all US shots administered.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.description: (Emerging Tech Brew) Read: Your definitive guide to autonomous vehicles. The main culprits: wealthy Americans and large corporations.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Q&A: What Are Company Earnings, Why do They Affect Stocks?
item.description: Question from Reha in Boston: How does a company's quarterly earnings report affect its stock price? But an earnings report can also show metrics like revenue, subscriber counts (in the case of companies like Netflix), and predictions for future performance, aka "guidance." Then, execs usually host a conference call to parse the data in front of analysts and whichever media interns drew the short stick."
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Consumer Prices Rise More Than Expected in March
item.description: A big annual increase in prices simply doesn't tell us much when the point of comparison is so abnormal. That's a recipe for a price bump. Some economists are concerned that too much stimulus will cause an overheated economy.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: US Regulators Recommend Pause for Johnson & Johnson Vaccine
item.description: To-date, J&J has accounted for <5% of all US shots administered. Yesterday, Johnson & Johnson joined millions of disappointed students on dreaded waitlists after the CDC and FDA recommended pausing its single-dose Covid vaccine while they investigate reports of rare blood clots. While all J&J shots administered through federal channels are paused, state vaccine programs can make their own decisions.  The agencies say this is out of an "abundance of caution" while they determine if the vaccine caused rare blood clots and low platelet counts in six women shortly after their vaccination.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Domino's Partners with Nuro to Deliver Pizza via Driverless Vehicle
item.description: Chipotle invested in Nuro's $500 million Series C funding round last month and the company was just approved at the end of last year to begin testing on public roads in California. From a sales and drunk on High Life POV, Domino's pizza is the top pizza chain in the country.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Key Performance Indicators
item.description: (Dror Poleg)  Read: The future of work is a pyramid scheme, where every person sells his favorite person to the next person. Yesterday, Uber said total monthly bookings, which include ride-hailing and food delivery, hit record levels in March.  Khosrowshahi is high on the company's trajectory.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Ant Group Forced to Undergo Major Restructuring
item.description: It wasn't clear exactly why proceedings stopped but, the month before the planned offering, Jack Ma, the billionaire controlling shareholder of Ant and cofounder of Ant's sister company, Alibaba, criticized Chinese officials in a high-profile speech.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Will Smith's Upcoming Movie Pulls out of Georgia Over New Voting Law
item.description: Will Smith and director Antoine Fuqua announced yesterday they would pull production of their upcoming film out of Georgia because of the state's new controversial voting law.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Microsoft to Buy Speech Tech Company Nuance for $16B
item.description: Big picture: Microsoft worked on speech tech for years, but has had less success in the consumer market than Amazon or Google.    With Nuance, Microsoft scores a big list of healthcare clients + lots of speech data, which is important for building and fine-tuning those AI systems.  In the US, over half of physicians and three-quarters of hospitals use Nuance software.  This year, it reportedly dangled over $50 billion in front of Pinterest and is in talks to buy Discord for $10+ billion. The Nuance acquisition could catapult it ahead. er, nuance of human language.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Ant Group Forced to Undergo Major Restructuring
item.description: It wasn't clear exactly why proceedings stopped but, the month before the planned offering, Jack Ma, the billionaire controlling shareholder of Ant and cofounder of Ant's sister company, Alibaba, criticized Chinese officials in a high-profile speech.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: (Dror Poleg)  Read: The future of work is a pyramid scheme, where every person sells his favorite person to the next person. Yesterday, Uber said total monthly bookings, which include ride-hailing and food delivery, hit their highest levels ever in March.  Khosrowshahi is feeling high on the company's trajectory.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Microsoft to Buy Speech Tech Company Nuance for $16B
item.description: Big picture: Microsoft worked on speech tech for years, but has had less success in the consumer market than Amazon or Google.    With Nuance, Microsoft scores a big list of healthcare clients + lots of speech data, which is important for building and fine-tuning those AI systems.  In the US, over half of physicians and three-quarters of hospitals use Nuance software.  This year, it reportedly dangled over $50 billion in front of Pinterest and is in talks to buy Discord for $10+ billion. The Nuance acquisition could catapult it ahead. er, nuance of human language.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: The Week Ahead: April 12
item.description: Economic data: The biggest report of the week is Tuesday’s Consumer Price Index, which will reveal how worried we should actually be about inflation.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: April 12
item.description: Quote: Chinese vaccines “don’t have very high protection rates.” (The Atlantic)   Read: America is about to go Botox wild.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Recapping the Busy Weekend in Sports Biz
item.description: Japan is very into golf—it has as many courses as the UK + Ireland combined. Golf history: With his victory at the Masters, Hideki Matsuyama became the first male Japanese golfer to win a major tournament. he’s selling it for $1.5 billion.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: CEOs Made More Than Ever In The Pandemic
item.description: Case in point: Paycom CEO Chad RichisonHe’s the newly crowned highest-paid CEO in the S&P 500 with a total compensation of $211 million in 2020.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Company Execs Meet at White House Over Chip Shortage
item.description: Sony said the chip shortage is the reason why there are so few PS5s available.  Senior execs from almost 20 companies are heading to the White House today to discuss the current chip shortage and ensure more supply chain chaos doesn’t break out in the future.  But it’s a big problemThe chip shortage has affected “virtually every major car company in recent months,” according to the WSJ, forcing automakers to halt production of their most popular cars. Those will take years and hundreds of billions worth of investments to resolve.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.description: Quote: Chinese vaccines “don’t have very high protection rates.” (The Atlantic)   Read: America is about to go Botox wild.

Those will take years and hundreds of billions worth of investments to resolve.

item.title: Recapping the Busy Weekend in Sports Biz
item.description: The Timberwolves are getting new owners: Fresh off losing a bidding war for the NY Mets, baseball star-turned-businessman Alex Rodriguez is teaming up with e-commerce legend Marc Lore to buy the NBA’s Minnesota Timberwolves and the WNBA’s Minnesota Lynx.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: New York Raises Income Taxes on Super Wealthy, Raising Concerns Among Corporations
item.description: This week, state lawmakers passed a budget that raises the personal income tax on individuals making over $1 million and introduces two new brackets for those making more than $5 million and $25 million. That’s not a record some New Yorkers want to break250 business executives have sent a letter to state lawmakers arguing that higher taxes would “jeopardize New York’s recovery from the economic crisis inflicted by Covid-19” by sending high-net-worth people fleeing.
item.author: Neal Freyman
